title: Two New Adenine-Based Co(II) Coordination Polymers: Synthesis, Crystal Structure, Coordination Modes, and Reversible Hydrochromic Behavior
abstract: Two new three-dimensional coordination polymers (CPs) based on Co(II), adenine, and aromatic tetracarboxylate linkers and an analysis of the coordination modes of adenine found in extended coordination structures are reported. Interestingly, one of these CPs shows reversible hydrochromic behavior, exhibiting a detectable color change from pink to purple, and

We report the synthesis of two new three-dimensional coordination polymers (CPs) based on Co(II), adenine, and aromatic tetracarboxylate linkers. Adenine exhibits bidentate binding modes in both CPs, coordinating through the N
sites in a first compact CP and through the more rare N
sites in a second open, flexible, and H

O-responsive CP. These differences together with an analysis of the extended coordination structures made of adenine reported in the Cambridge Structural Database illustrate the rich coordination versatility of adenine as a building block for CPs. Although the latter CP is nonporous to N
, it shows a reversible and detectable color change from pink to purple, and
text: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (CPs) are among the most attractive porous materials today, owing to their potential for applications such as gas storage;
The infinite possibilities for connecting functional organic ligands to metal ions and clusters enable the formation of countless CPs with a range of pore sizes and shapes,
extremely large surface areas, tailored internal surfaces,
and flexible structures that give rise to novel phenomena such as gate-opening

Biorelated linkers such as amino acids, peptides, and nucleobases are very attractive building blocks that can be used for the formation of CPs due to their large number of oxygen and nitrogen atoms with different basicity that are available for metal coordination.
In particular, adenine is a rigid connector with five potential coordination sites for metal binding: two imidazolate, two pyrimidinate N atoms, and a NH
group with a basicity order of N
). It provides the widest range of neutral tautomers
and the noncoordinated nitrogen donor sites, especially Watson–Crick (N
) faces, can interact through hydrogen bonding.

Its rich metal binding and H-bonding capabilities, together with the rigidity of its molecular structure, make adenine an ideal biolinker for constructing topologically diverse CPs. For instance, adenine has been used to build up robust porous CPs with applications for example in drug encapsulation and in the selective adsorption of greenhouse gases such as CO

High Capacity Hydrogen Adsorption in Cu(II) Tetracarboxylate Framework Materials: The Role of Pore Size, Ligand Functionalization, and Exposed Metal Sites

Lin, Xiang; Telepeni, Irvin; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Brown, Craig M.; Simmons, Jason M.; Zoppi, Marco; Walker, Gavin S.; Thomas, K. Mark; Mays, Timothy J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Isostructural metal-org. framework polymers [Cu2(L)(H2O)2] (L = tetracarboxylate ligands), denoted NOTT-nnn, were synthesized and characterized.  Single crystal x-ray structures confirm the complexes to contain binuclear Cu(II) paddlewheel nodes each bridged by four carboxylate centers to give a NbO-type network of 64·82 topol.  These complexes are activated by solvent exchange with acetone coupled to heating cycles under vacuum to afford the desolvated porous materials NOTT-100 to NOTT-109.  These incorporate a vacant coordination site at each Cu(II) center and have large pore vols. that contribute to the obsd. high H2 adsorption.  Indeed, NOTT-103 at 77 K and 60 bar shows a very high total H2 adsorption of 77.8 mg g-1 equiv. to 7.78% [wt% = (wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material)] or 7.22% [wt% = 100(wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material + wt. of adsorbed H2)].  Neutron powder diffraction studies on NOTT-101 reveal three adsorption sites for this material: at the exposed Cu(II) coordination site, at the pocket formed by three {Cu2} paddle wheels, and at the cusp of three Ph rings.  Systematic virial anal. of the H2 isotherms suggests that the H2 binding energies at these sites are very similar and the differences are smaller than 1.0 kJ mol-1, although the adsorption enthalpies for H2 at the exposed Cu(II) site are significantly affected by pore metrics.  Introducing Me groups or using kinked ligands to create smaller pores can enhance the isosteric heat of adsorption and improve H2 adsorption.  However, although increasing the overlap of potential energy fields of pore walls increases the heat of H2 adsorption at low pressure, it may be detrimental to the overall adsorption capacity by reducing the pore vol.
Oriented Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework-8 Membrane with Sharp H2/C3H8 Molecular Sieve Separation
Bux, Helge; Feldhoff, Armin; Cravillon, Janosch; Wiebcke, Michael; Li, Yan-Shuo; Caro, Juergen

A highly oriented zeolitic imidazolate framework 8 (ZIF-8) composite membrane was prepd. by seeding and secondary growth.  By dip-coating, preformed ZIF-8 nanocrystals were attached to the surface of a porous α-alumina support using polyethyleneimine as the coupling agent.  After solvothermal treatment, a continuous and well-intergrown ZIF-8 layer was obtained.  X-ray diffraction anal. of the membrane showed preferred orientation of the {100} plane parallel to the support.  Further time-dependent studies by scanning and TEM as well as x-ray diffraction indicated that the preferred orientation develops during an evolutionary growth process.  In gas mixt. permeation expts., the membrane showed good performance in H2/hydrocarbon sepn.  A sharp mol. sieve sepn. is obsd. for an equimolar H2/C3H8 mixt. with a sepn. factor >300.
Size-Selective Lewis Acid Catalysis in a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework with Exposed Mn2+ Coordination Sites
Horike, Satoshi; Dinca, Mircea; Tamaki, Kentaro; Long, Jeffrey R.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Treatment of selected aldehydes and ketones R1COR2 (R1 = Ph, R2 = H, Me; R1 = 4-PhC6H4, 4-PhOC6H4, 1-naphthyl, R2 = H) with Me3SiCN in the presence of the microporous metal-org. framework Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3BTT8(CH3OH)10]2 (I, H3BTT = 1,3,5-benzenetristetrazol-5-yl) leads to rapid conversion to the corresponding cyanosilylated products R1R2C(CN)OSiMe3.  The transformation is catalyzed by coordinatively unsatd. Mn2+ ions that serve as Lewis acids and lead to conversion yields of 98 and 90% for benzaldehyde and 1-naphthaldehyde, the highest thus far for a metal-org. framework.  Larger carbonyl substrates cannot diffuse through the pores of I, and conversion yields are much lower for these, attesting to the heterogeneity of the reaction and its dependence on guest size.  The Mukaiyama-aldol reaction, known to require much more active Lewis catalysts, is also catalyzed in the presence of I, representing the first such example for a metal-org. framework.  Conversion yields obtained for the reaction of benzaldehyde with silyl enolate Me2C:C(OMe)OSiMe3 reach 63%, on par with those obtained with zeolites.  Size selectivity is demonstrated for the first time with this reaction through the use of larger silyl enolate substrates.
A Guest-Responsive Fluorescent 3D Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Derived from a Long-Lifetime Pyrene Core
Stylianou, Kyriakos C.; Heck, Romain; Chong, Samantha Y.; Bacsa, John; Jones, James T. A.; Khimyak, Yaroslav Z.; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The carboxylate ligand pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetrakis(p-benzoic acid) (TBAPy), based on the strongly fluorescent long-lifetime pyrene core, affords a permanently microporous fluorescent metal-org. framework, [In2(OH)2(TBAPy)]·(guests) (1), displaying 54% total accessible vol. and excellent thermal stability.  Fluorescence studies reveal that both 1 and TBAPy display strong emission bands at 471 and 529 nm, resp., upon excitation at 390 nm, with framework coordination of the TBAPy ligands significantly increasing the emission lifetime from 0.089 to 0.110 ms.  Upon desolvation, the emission band for the framework is shifted to lower energy: however, upon re-exposure to DMF the as-made material is regenerated with reversible fluorescence behavior.  Together with the lifetime, the emission intensity is strongly enhanced by spatial sepn. of the optically active ligand mols. within the MOF structure and is dependent on the amt. and chem. nature of the guest species in the pores.  The quantum yield of the material is 6.7% and, coupled with the fluorescence lifetime on the millisecond time scale, begins to approach the values obsd. for Eu(III)-cryptate-derived com. sensors.
MOFs as Adsorbents for Low Temperature Heating and Cooling Applications
Henninger, Stefan K.; Habib, Hesham A.; Janiak, Christoph
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The 3D metal-org. framework (MOF) 3∞{[Ni3(μ3-btc)2(μ4-btre)2(μ-H2O)2]·∼22H2O} is found to be a reversibly dehydratable-hydratable water-stable MOF material with a large loading spread of 210 g/kg as a candidate for solid adsorbents in heat transformation cycles for refrigeration, heat pumping, and heat storage.

Metal organic frameworks with high capacity and selectivity for harmful gases
Britt, David; Tranchemontagne, David; Yaghi, Omar M.
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

Benchmarks have been established for the performance of six metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and isoreticular MOFs (IRMOFs, which have the same underlying topol. as MOF-5), MOF-5, IRMOF-3, MOF-74, MOF-177, MOF-199, and IRMOF-62, as selective adsorbents for eight harmful gases: sulfur dioxide, ammonia, chlorine, tetrahydrothiophene, benzene, dichloromethane, ethylene oxide, and carbon monoxide.  Kinetic breakthrough measurements are used to det. the calcd. dynamic adsorption capacity of each "benchmark" MOF for each gas.  The capacity of each MOF is compared to that of a sample of Calgon BPL activated carbon.  We find that pore functionality plays a dominant role in detg. the dynamic adsorption performance of MOFs.  MOFs featuring reactive functionality outperform BPL carbon in all but one case and exhibit high dynamic adsorption capacities up to 35% by wt.
Relaxometry Studies of a Highly Stable Nanoscale Metal-Organic Framework Made of Cu(II), Gd(III), and the Macrocyclic DOTP
Carne-Sanchez, Arnau; Bonnet, Celia S.; Imaz, Inhar; Lorenzo, Julia; Toth, Eva; Maspoch, Daniel
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The macrocyclic ligand DOTP was used to assemble a porous, heterometallic metal-org. framework (MOF).  This MOF is miniaturizable down to the nanoscale to form stable colloids, is stable in physiol. saline soln. and cell culture media, and is not cytotoxic.  It shows interesting relaxometric properties with r1 at high field (500 MHz) of 5 mM-1 s-1 and a max. r1 = 15 mM-1 s-1 at 40 MHz, which remains const. over a wide pH range and increases with temp.

The reaction of nucleobases (adenine or purine) with a metallic salt in the presence of K oxalate in an aq. soln. yields 1-dimensional complexes [M(μ-ox)(H2O)(pur)]n (pur = purine, ox = oxalato ligand (2-); M = Cu(II) (1), Co(II) (2), and Zn(II) (3)), [Co(μ-ox)(H2O)(pur)0.76(ade)0.24]n (4) and {[M(μ-ox)(H2O)(ade)]·2(ade)·(H2O)}n (ade = adenine; M = Co(II) (5) and Zn(II) (6)).  Their x-ray single-crystal structures, variable-temp. magnetic measurements, thermal behavior, and FTIR spectroscopy are reported.  The complexes 1-4 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/a with similar crystallog. parameters.  The compds. 5 and 6 are also isomorphous but crystallize in the triclinic space group P‾1.  All compds. contain 1-dimensional chains in which cis-[M(H2O)(L)]2+ units are bridged by bis-bidentate oxalato ligands with M···M intrachain distances in the range 5.23-5.57 Å.  In all cases, the metal atoms are six-coordinated by four oxalato O atoms, one H2O mol., and one N atom from a terminal nucleobase, building distorted octahedral MO4OwN surroundings.  The purine ligand is bound to the metal atom through the most basic imidazole N9 atom in 1-4, whereas in 5 and 6 the minor groove site N3 of the adenine nucleobase is the donor atom.  The crystal packing of compds. 5 and 6 shows uncoordinated adenine and H2O crystn. mols.  The cohesiveness of the supramol. 3-dimensional structure of the compds. is achieved by an extensive network of noncovalent interactions (H bonds and π-π stacking interactions).  Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements of the Cu(II) and Co(II) complexes in the range 2-300 K show the occurrence of antiferromagnetic intrachain interactions.
Supramolecular architectures of metal-oxalato complexes containing purine nucleobases
Perez-Yanez, Sonia; Castillo, Oscar; Cepeda, Javier; Garcia-Teran, Juan P.; Luque, Antonio; Roman, Pascual

The reaction of purine nucleobases (adenine (Hade), 3-methyladenine (3Meade) and 9-methylguanine (9Megua)) with a metallic salt in the presence of potassium oxalate yields three compds. {[Cd(μ-ox)(H2O)(Hade)]·H2O}n (1), {[Cu(μ-ox)(H2O)(3Meade)]·H2O}n (2) and [Cu(ox)(H2O)2(9Megua)]·2.5H2O (3).  Crystal structures of compds. 1-2 consist of 1-dimensional zigzag chains in which cis-[M(H2O)(nucleobase)]2+ fragments are linked by bis-bidentate oxalato ligands.  In compd. 1, the nucleobase is coordinated through the minor groove N3 atom, and the resulting noncanonical 7H-adenine tautomer is stabilized by noncovalent interactions involving more basic N9 and N7 sites.  In compd. 2, the mutagenic 3-methyladenine is attached to the metal atoms by the imidazole N7 atom.  The dissimilar binding pattern of the nucleobases produces significant differences in the supramol. architectures of compds. 1 and 2 which are essentially governed by an extensive network of noncovalent interactions such as H bonded adenine-adenine base pairs, hydration of the nucleobases, carboxylato-nucleobase assocns., and face-to-face π-π stacking.  The model 9-methylguanine nucleobase of compd. 3 exhibits its usual coordination mode through the major groove N7 atom to form two monomeric [(Cu(ox)(H2O)2(9Megua))] units which are held together by Watson-Crick like H bonds between the guanine moieties and the inorg. frameworks generating almost planar tetrameric metal-org. aggregates.  The 3-dimensional packing of the complex entities affords an open structure contg. voids which are filled by decameric (H2O)10 clusters.  Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements of compd. 2 show the occurrence of antiferromagnetic intrachain interactions in good agreement with the structural features of its 1-dimensional metal-oxalato framework.

When BP@DMF was exposed to air, it converted into [Co1.5(tipb)(SO4)(H2O)3.6](pta)0.5DMFx (RP-H2O) without losing crystallinity, which in turn converted into BP upon slow loss of water.  A sample of BP@CH3OH was obtained from BP@DMF via solvent exchange.  Gas adsorption of CO2, CH4, N2, methanol, ethanol, and water by the BP was studied.  The reversible response of this material to H2O/NH3 makes it a good candidate as a sensor material.
